Award.AwardTitle: Ion Beam Linking and Ion Beam Welding of Continuously Pulled Carbon Nanotube Yarns

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
In this research, we study the effects of ion beam welding on structural and property changes of carbon nanotube yarn. The approach of this research will be creating carbon nanotube yarn by continuous pulling from self-aligned nanotube arrays, and immediately irradiating the yarn by using an ion beam in air. The key is to use ion bombardment to introduce inter-tube displacements as stable contacts between tubes or to locally weld the junction of two joining carbon nanotubes, in order to enhance inter-tube electrical conduction, phonon transport and tube sliding friction. Ion beam treated yarns are expected to have significantly enhanced thermal, electrical and mechanical properties. The ion irradiation effects are characterized by using electron microscopy, Raman spectroscopy, tensile testing, electrical resistance and heat conduction experiments. This research includes multi-scale modeling to reveal atomic-scale details of evolution of defects created by ion irradiation, how subsequent structural relaxation leads to stable defect configurations, and how defects influence various properties at spatial and temporal scales linkable to experiments.

If successful, the benefits of this research will include development of an industry-ready ion beam technique for creation of yarns or ropes of high strength and conductivity. The technique can be extended to other non-carbon systems for materials applications under harsh environments. The project will also have broad impact with its educational plans to increase minority student participation, develop curricula, and create e-learning resources to promote public learning in frontiers of nanotechnology. The research activities will be integrated with existing Undergraduate Student Research Scholar Program and Enrichment Experience in Engineering for Teachers Program at the Texas A&M University to promote undergraduate student and high school teacher participation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project studied the effect of ion beam linking/welding on structural and property changes of carbon nanotube yarns. The past decades have witnessed an enormous increase in interests on carbon nanomaterials such as carbon nanotubes and carbon fibers. Carbon nanotube bundles or fibers, however, are held together through relatively weak van der Waals forces. The lack of strong structural integrity has become a bottleneck for further technology application. In this project, carbon nanotube yarns were created by continuously pulling from self-aligned nanotube arrays, and were immediately exposed to an ion beam in air or in vacuum. Ion-solid interactions created carbon displacements which acted as stable point contacts between tubes. Subsequent structural rearrangements led to linking or welding of adjacent tubes, which modified electronic, mechanical and thermal properties of nanotube yarns. The proposed carbon yarn fabrication device and its integration with ion accelerators have been successfully demonstrated and optimized. Various ion irradiation conditions have been tested and the property changes have been systematically studied. The experimental results were integrated with modeling to reveal the fundamentals. The project impacted ion beam modification and defect engineering of nanomaterials. The project trained two Ph.D students and two undergraduate students. The research findings are integrated with teaching to educate students about frontiers of radiation materials science.


Last Modified: 12/03/2017
Modified by: Lin Shao

The past decades have witnessed an enormous increase in interests on carbon nanomaterials such as carbon nanotubes and carbon fibers. Carbon nanotube bundles or fibers, however, are held together through relatively weak van der Waals forces. The lack of strong structural integrity has become a bottleneck for further technology application. In this project, carbon nanotube yarns were created by continuously pulling from self-aligned nanotube arrays, and were immediately exposed to an ion beam in air or in vacuum. Ion-solid interactions created carbon displacements which acted as stable point contacts between tubes. The proposed carbon yarn fabrication device and its integration with ion accelerators have been successfully demonstrated and optimized. Various ion irradiation conditions have been tested and the property changes have been systematically studied. The experimental results were integrated with modeling to reveal the fundamentals. The project impacted ion beam modification and defect engineering of nanomaterials. The project trained two Ph.D students and two undergraduate students.
